questions.text: A 15 days old child is brought to the paediatric emergency with complaints of vomiting and poor feeding. On examination, oil drop cataract is seen bilaterally. Biochemical evaluation shows the GALT enzymatic deficiency. On urine examination, what is the likely finding?
questions.solution: The child has galactosemia. GALT enzyme is another name for Gal-1Phosphate Uridyl Transferase, which is deficient in Galactosemia. Galactose is elevated in blood and appears in urine; hence Benedict’s test is positive.

questions.text: On weaning off from milk and addition of fruit juices, an infant had frequent attacks of vomiting and tremors. Urine reducing sugar was positive but glucose was negative. The infant is likely to have
questions.solution:
Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is an inborn error of fructose metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme aldolase B. It is an autosomal recessive condition. Individuals affected with HFI are asymptomatic until they ingest fructose, sucrose, or sorbitol. If fructose is ingested, the enzymatic block at aldolase B causes an accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate. This accumulation has downstream effects on gluconeogenesis and regeneration of adenosine triphosphate (ATP). Symptoms of HFI include vomiting, hypoglycemia, jaundice, hemorrhage, hepatomegaly, hyperuricemia and potentially kidney failure.

Hence, typically, a patient of hereditary fructose intolerance remains asymptomatic till the time of 'weaning'.

questions.text: A child ingested cyanide and rushed to the emergency room. Which of the following enzymes of citric acid cycle is first to be inhibited? (AI-2016-May-9)
questions.solution: Cyanide will block ETC, complex IV. ETC is responsible for regenerating NAD from NADH. If ETC is blocked, NAD cannot be regenerated efficiently.

questions.text: A reaction in which substrate concentration was 1000 times Km, after 9 minutes, 1% of substrate is converted to product which is 12 mol. if the substrate concentration is doubled and enzyme concentration is changed to one third, what would be the time taken to produce same amount of product? (AI-2018-May-17)
questions.solution:
Two points to remember here:

  1. Reaction velocity has linear relationship with enzyme concentration
  2. Beyond a certain concentration of substrate (typically after 5-10 Km), further increase in substrate concentration cannot affect the reaction velocity.

questions.text: The bone marrow is actually one of the largest organs in the body, approaching the size and weight of the liver. It is also one of the most active organs as well. Normally, 75% of the cells in the marrow belong to the white blood cell-producing myeloid series and only 25% are maturing red cells, even though there are over 500 times as many red cells in the circulation as there are white cells. This difference in the marrow reflects the fact that the average life span of white cells is short, whereas that ofred cells is long. Site of RBC formation in a 25-year-old healthy male is?
questions.solution:
Erythropoiesis :

  • 1st trimester - in mesoderm of yolk sac(Mesoblastic stage);
  • 2nd trimester - liver & spleen (Hepatic stage);6 months onward - bone marrow (Myeloid stage). 
  • At birth - all bones have red bone marrow,producing cells. Progressively, bone marrow turns yellow; shafts of long bones first turn yellow,followed by their ends. So from birth till 20 years-source is Axial skeleton and long bones. By 20 years - red marrow exists only in sternum, ribs, vertebrae, pelvis and skull[flat bones]

REFERENCE Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 13th Edition pg. 61

questions.text: The prime driving force for counter current multiplier system is:
questions.solution:
The major factors that contribute to the buildup of solute concentration into the renal medulla are as follows:

  1. Active transport of sodium ions and co-transport of potassium, chloride, and other ions out of TAL into the medullary interstitium
  2. Active transport of ions from CD into the medullary interstitium.
  3. Facilitated diffusion of large amounts of urea from the inner MCD into the medullary interstitium
  4. Diffusion of only small amounts of water from the medullary tubules into the medullary interstitium

questions.text: A 43-year-old man eats a meal consisting of 40 percent protein, 10 percent fat, and 50 percent carbohydrate. Thirty minutes later the man feels the urge to defecate.
questions.solution:
The appearance of mass movements after meals is facilitated by gastrocolic and duodenocolic reflexes. These reflexes result from distention of the stomach and duodenum. They are greatly suppressed when the extrinsic autonomic nerves to the colon have been removed; therefore, the reflexes are likely transmitted by way of the autonomic nervous system.

All the gut reflexes are named with the anatomical origin of the reflex as the prefix followed by the name of the gut segment in which the outcome of the reflex is observed:

  • The duodeno-colic reflex begins in the duodenum and ends in the colon. When the duodenum is distended, nervous signals are transmitted to the colon, which stimulates mass movements.
  • The enterogastric reflex occurs when signals originating in the intestines inhibit gastric motility and gastric secretion.
  • The intestino-intestinal reflex occurs when overdistention or injury to a bowel segment signals the bowel to relax.
  • The rectosphincteric reflex, also called the defecation reflex, is initiated when feces enters the rectum and stimulates the urge to defecate.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with fatigue and back pain. He has also had tea coloured urine over the last 24 hours. Upon being asked about changes to his routine over the last week, he remembers running a 5K, trying alcohol with a friend, and having a large meal at a friend's house with ingredients that he did not recognize. On physical exam he appears to be pale with conjunctival pallor. Labs are as follows:Hemoglobin: 11 g/dL, Hematocrit: 32%, Mean Corpuscular Volume: 88 fL Peripheral blood smear findings are shown in Figure A. An enzyme defect in which of the following pathways is likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• This case is most consistent with a diagnosis of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD). G6P is the first committed enzyme in the HMP shunt and this pathway functions to generate NADPH for neutralizing oxidizing agents.
  • The symptom of fatigue accompanied by pallor immediately suggests that the question deals with an anemia, a suspicion confirmed by the decreased hemoglobin and hematocrit. The first step to differentiating anemias is the MCV, which is found to be normal indicating that this case is a normocytic anemia. The 'tea - colored urine' and the back pain are indicative of haemoglobinuria meaning that this case is an intrinsic hemolytic anemia. Abnormal RBCs on peripheral blood smear and triggering events can be used to further explore the differential. The peripheral blood smear shows Heinz bodies as well as bite cells, both of which are classic findings in G6PD. Of the potential triggering factors listed, a 5K might cause mild hemolysis but would not be associated with anemia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is brought to the physician by his wife who is concerned because he has begun to demonstrate odd behavior which has worsened over the past several months. She states that he has become very aggressive and at times will have sudden, jerky movements which he is unable to control. The patient states that his father had the same problem which he died of at age 69. The patient had a recent, 'cold', with fevers, chills and, 'throat pain', which resolved on its own, 'some time ago'. Which of the following is true of this disease?
questions.solution:
• The phenomenon of anticipation refers to the tendency for clinical symptoms to worsen and/or occur earlier in subsequent generations of people with certain genetic diseases. This patient is presenting with key findings of Huntington's disease including hemiballismus and personality changes which demonstrates anticipation via CAG repeats on chromosome 4.
  • Certain genetic diseases demonstrate anticipation, increased severity, and earlier onset of clinical symptoms in successive generations. The diseases exhibiting the phenomenon of anticipation include the trinucleotide repeat expansion diseases such as Huntington's disease, Myotonic Dystrophy, Friedreich's ataxia, and Fragile X syndrome. Anticipation is caused by the progressive increase in trinucleotide repeats in each successive generation, thereby causing increased genetic disruption and increased symptom severity.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with a history of uncontrolled hypertension undergoes kidney transplantation. One month following surgery she has elevated serum blood urea nitrogen and creatinine and the patient complains of fever and arthralgia. Her medications include tacrolimus and prednisone. If the patient were experiencing acute, cell-mediated rejection, which of the following findings is likely to be seen upon biopsy of the transplanted kidney?
questions.solution:
• Cell-mediated, acute allograft rejection occurs when cytotoxic T lymphocytes react against foreign MHCs. It is marked histologically by lymphocytic infiltrate of the tubules and interstitium.
  • Acute, cell-mediated rejection can occur from a few weeks to 6 months following kidney transplantation. Lymphatic infiltrate in the tubules and interstitium is seen upon renal biopsy. This process often results in parenchymal cell damage and/or graft vasculitis. A quick way to differentiate acute transplant rejection from hyperacute and chronic rejection is by a time-line approach: hyperacute occurs within minutes of transplant, acute occurs within weeks, and chronic occurs months to years after transplant.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child is found to have a disease involving DNA repair. Specifically, he is found to have a defect in the endonucleases involved in the nucleotide excision repair of pyrimidine dimers. Which of the following is a unique late stage complication of this child's disease?
questions.solution:
• This child has xeroderma pigmentosum (XP), a disease in which there is a mutation in endonucleases involved in repairing pyrimidine dimers formed by exposure to ultraviolet (UV) light. Patients with XP are very sensitive to UV light exposure and have an increased risk of cutaneous malignancies, including malignant melanoma
  • XP is an autosomal recessive disease in which there is a defect in the DNA repair mechanisms. In particular, in XP repair in response to DNA damaged by ultraviolet (UV) light is deficient. This disease affects approximately 1 in 250,000 people in the United States. XP often leads to extreme sunlight sensitivity with severe sunburns, freckling, dry and scaly skin, photophobia, corneal ulcers, and ocular cancers. XP patients have an increased risk for cutaneous malignancies, metastatic melanoma and squamous cell carcinoma are the leading cause of death in patients with XP.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with small cell lung cancer undergoes radiation therapy. His oncologist explains that radiation causes DNA damage and double strand breaks and this damage stops the cancer cells from growing because they can no longer replicate their DNA. One key mediator of this process is a cell cycle regulator called P53, which is upregulated after DNA damage and helps to trigger cell cycle arrest and apoptosis. One mechanism by which P53 activity is increased is a certain chromatin modification that loosens DNA coiling allowing for greater transcription of the proteins within that region of DNA. Which of the following enyzmes most likely causes the chromatin modification described in this case?
questions.solution:
• The process described is most consistent with acetylation of histones leading to electrostatic repulsion from DNA and loosening of DNA packaging. This process increases transcription of the genes located near the acetylated histones
  • Chromatin consists of DNA packaged into nucleosomes along with a core histone octamer. These small, positively charged proteins attract negatively charged DNA allowing for 2 loops of DNA to wrap around each octamer. These DNA-histone interactions must be unwound for transcriptional machinery to efficiently activate DNA transcription so the state of chromatin packaging is important in protein expression levels. Methylation and acetylation of chromatin structures is the most well characterized method of controlling the winding of DNA in nucleosomes. Uncharged modifications such as methylation make the DNA structure more compact and decrease transcription whereas charged modifications such as acetylation unwind the nucleosome structure and increase transcription. Transcriptionally repressed chromatin is called heterochromatin and is dense on microscopy. Transcriptionally active chromatin is called euchromatin and is diffuse on microscopy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy with a history of seizures presents to the pediatrician for several seizures occurring over the past month. The mother states that her son typically avoids recess, as he exhausts quite easily with any physical activity. He has also had headaches and vomits after he eats. A family history reveals that a maternal uncle and grandmother both had similar symptoms and both lost their vision and hearing by the age of 40. The mother explains that she also tires easily. With consent of the mother, a muscle biopsy was taken and a Gomori trichrome stain was performed (image). A blood analysis also revealed significantly elevated lactate levels. Which of the following statement best describes the mode of inheritance of the boy's disease?
questions.solution:
• The boy suffers from a mitochondrial disease called mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes (MELAS). MELAS has a mitochondrial inheritance pattern and is best described by the statement 'transmission only occurs from females and may have variable expression.'
  • Mitochondrial diseases are inherited only from females with affected mitochondria. The mother will pass it onto all of her offspring (both males and females affected at equal frequency) due to the fact that sperm do not contribute mitochondria to the zygote. The disease may present differently depending on the percentage of mitochondria affected and the cell type containing the diseased mitochondria. This variable expression is termed heteroplasmy. Representative mitochondrial diseases are MELAS, Leber hereditary optic neuropathy, and MERRF.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with a three-month history of oral ulcerations and blisters throughout her body. When the physician examined the skin, she noted that when the skin was rubbed it sloughed off and formed blisters within a few minutes. A skin biopsy was performed and analysed via immunofluorescence using anti-IgG antibodies (image). Which of the following antibodies is also involved or found in a similar type of hypersensitivity reaction as in the case mentioned?
questions.solution:
• The female in the clinical vignette has pemphigus vulgaris which is a type I hypersensitivity reaction caused by antibodies against desmosomes, specifically the protein desmoglein 3. Anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies cause Goodpasture's syndrome which is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.
  • There are four types of hypersensitivity reactions (1-IV). Type I is an immediate allergic response that occurs when preformed IgE crosslinks with an antigen on pre sensitized mast cells and basophils releasing histamine and heparin. Type II is a cytotoxic, antibody-mediated response in which antibodies target specific proteins or cells within the body for destruction. Type III is an immune complex-mediated response in which antigen-antibody complexes are not cleared properly resulting in their deposition in various tissues or blood vessels, the activation of the complement, and the destruction of the tissues by neutrophils. Type IV is a T-cell-mediated, delayed hypersensitivity reaction which is independent of antibodies.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician for continuing management of a chronic lung infection. He has had many lung infections throughout childhood, and current sputum samples show oxidase positive, non-lactose fermenting gram-negative rods that produce a blue-green pigment. Physical exam shows nasal polyps and nail clubbing. He has also recently been experiencing floating foul smelling diarrhea, so he is prescribed enzymes and vitamin supplementation tablets. Which of the following chromosomes most likely contains the gene mutation responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• This case is most consistent with a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis, which is most commonly caused by a phenylalanine deletion at position 508 of the CFTR gene on chromosome 7
  • Chronic infections in childhood are generally caused by an inherited defect in the body's defenes mechanisms. These mutations can either affect immune system cells or the physical mechanisms protecting exposed membrane surfaces. In this case, the patient suffers from chronic lung infections that are most likely caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa given the production of the characteristic blue/green pigment pyocyanin This infection is closely associated with cystic fibrosis. The diagnosis of cystic fibrosis is supported by the physical exam findings of nasal polyps and pancreatic insufficiency (as seen by the fatty diarrhea due to malabsorption). It is caused by autosomal recessive inheritance of a deleterious mutation in the chloride channel CFTR. This leads to excessive reabsorption of salt & water from excretions, leading to a thick obstructive mucus in the lungs and pancreatic ducts.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with a blood type O negative blood group presents to the transplant clinic to discuss proceeding with allogeneic stem cell transplant. Which of the following would be an optimal donor?
questions.solution:
• HLA-identical sibling who is healthy and ABO compatible would be an optimal donor.
  • For hematologic malignancies, the syngeneic transplant has proven to result in higher relapse rates and would not be the recommended donor source. While ABO compatibility is important to consider in deciding an optimal donor, this is only a minor ABO mismatch.
  • Related donor transplants remain preferred to unrelated donor transplants, given that the lower rates of graft-versus host disease (GVHD) with related transplants.
  • There is no role for an umbilical cord transplant in a setting with available related donors.

questions.text: The dose of 6-mercaptopurine is reduced by up to 75% when given along with allopurinol because:
questions.solution:
6- MP is oxidized by the enzyme Xanthine oxidase and is converted to inactive metabolite 6-thiouric acid

This inactivation in hindered when allopurinol is co-administered (Usually administered to prevent hyperuricemia) due to its inherent mechanism of inhibiting the enzyme Xanthine oxidase, causing accumulation of 6-MP and thereby increased susceptibility to bone marrow suppression.

To prevent this, dose of 6-MP is decreased by up to 75%.

6- thioguanine is not oxidized, instead deaminated. So, there is no need for dose reduction when given along with allopurinol.

They are common childhood infections. None of the other viruses listed cause this constellation of symptoms.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male is seen at a sexually transmitted disease clinic for treatment of gonorrhea. Prior treatments for this disease have successfully eradicated the organism; however, the man has not changed his behavior and has been repeatedly reinfected. What is the most important strategy the organism employs which enables it to cause repeated infections?
questions.solution: • Neisseria gonorrhoeae spontaneously changes the composition of its pilin proteins by switching between the expression of several different pilin-encoding genes. Antigenic variation also occurs with the opa proteins through changes in the number of nucleotide repeats at the 5′ end of the gene. These changes occur during DNA replication and result in changes in the amino acid sequence of the opa proteins expressed in the cell membrane. Neisseria gonorrhoeae does not induce immune suppression or grow in alveolar macrophages. It is not encapsulated.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy developed bloody diarrhea after eating a poorly cooked hamburger. A few days later, he was hospitalized with oliguria and hypertension. With which organism is he most likely infected?
questions.solution:
• The case is descriptive of hemolytic uremic syndrome associated with infection with E. coli O157:H7. This strain of E. coli produces phage-associated Shiga toxins (Stx-1 and/or Stx-2) that are functionally and antigenically similar to that produced by Shigella dysenteriae. None of the other organisms listed are associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome, although some do cause a bloody diarrhea.
  • C. perfringens is associated with ingestion of contaminated meats but it causes watery diarrhea.
  • S. typhi causes typhoid fever.
  • Enteroinvasive E. coli strains do not cause haemolytic uraemic syndrome.

questions.text: Microscopic examination of a thin blood smear from a patient suspected of having malaria reveals numerous normal size erythrocytes without stippling but with ring stages, many with multiple ring stages and applique forms. Several erythrocytes show developing trophozoites that are spread across the erythrocytes in a band fashion. Which of the following is the most likely cause of infection?
questions.solution:
• Multiple ring stages and applique forms are indicative of P. falciparum; several erythrocytes show developing trophozoites that are spread across the erythrocytes in a band fashion that is indicative of P. malariae infection.
  • Normal size erythrocytes without stippling (Schuffner dots) would exclude P. vivax and P. ovale.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with a migratory rash with central clearing on the back of his neck. The child had recently been on vacation with his family and had gone hiking. The child's paediatrician observes the rash and suspects an infection with B. burgdorferi. Which of the following is thought to be a virulence factor of this organism?
questions.solution: • Differential expression of outer surface proteins is thought to be involved with virulence; answers A, B, C are incorrect: (A) intracellular growth in leukocytes is a virulence factor of Ehrlichia; (B) endotoxins are characteristic of gram-negative organisms, not Borrelia; (C) localization in reticuloendothelial cells occurs in infections with Francisella tularensis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old Caucasian male with cough and fever is found on chest X-ray to have a lung infiltrate, hilar adenopathy, and a right-sided pleural effusion. Lung tissue obtained from this patient reveals the findings below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• The image above shows a large spherule filled with small round endospores. Spherules are the tissue form of Coccidioides immitis. This is a dimorphic fungus that exists in the environment in the form of mould (hyphae). It is endemic to the desert areas of the United States and Mexico. Coccidioides can cause lung disease in immunocompetent people and disseminated disease in the immunocompromised.
  • Microscopic examination of body fluids, sputum, and tissue samples in 10% KOH or silver stain shows thick-walled spherules packed with endospores. Culture on Sabouraud’s agar and serology are also important in making the diagnosis.
  • Aspergillus fumigatus commonly causes pulmonary disease in immunocompromised patients. It has a mould form only. In tissue specimens Aspergillus is seen as septate hyphae that branch at 45° angles.
  • The characteristic appearance of Blastomyces dermatitidis is that of round yeast with broad-based budding. These yeasts have thick, doubly refractive walls.
  • Histoplasma capsulatum would be seen as small oval yeast forms within macrophages.

questions.text: Cholera like symptoms is produced by which of the following poisons?
questions.solution:
Gastro enteric type is m / c form of Acute Arsenic poisoning.
Initially stools are dark, stinking & bloody that turns into colourless, odourless & watery resembling rice water stools of Cholera.

Arsenic poisoning

  • Arsenious oxide or Arsenic trioxide is the most common form of arsenic used

  • Chronic toxicity

questions.text: Dead fetus never shows:
questions.solution:
Dead born usually shows Maceration, Rigor mortis or Mummification. Rarely, a child which has remained surrounded in amniotic fluid after death may get converted into Adipocere.

Adipocere (Saponification)

  • Commonly seen in bodies immersed in water or in damp warm environment
  • Gradual hydrolysis and hydrogenation of preexisting fats, to form insoluble soaps.
  • These soaps being acidic in nature inhibit the putrefactive bacteria.
  • The body fat is converted into palmitic, oleic, stearic and hydroxystearic acid by the fat splitting enzyme lecithinase, produced by clostridia group of organisms, mainly Clostridium perfringes
  • The water required for hydrolysis is obtained mainly from the body tissues.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman with a known history of lung cancer comes to the office due to hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. She has no disturbances in vision or hearing. On examination, there is loss of the gag reflex on the left side; when the patient is prompted to say 'ah', the uvula deviates to the right side. Her left shoulder is drooped and strength is reduced during left shoulder shrug testing. Chest x-ray shows a right lower lobe lung mass and several osteolytic rib lesions. MRI of the head also demonstrates multiple lesions consistent with metastasis. A lesion involving which of the following anatomical structures is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms
questions.solution:
All the signs indicate the involvement of 9th, 10th and 11th cranial nerves, which passes through jugular foramen.

The main structures which pass through the jugular foramen are the glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), and spinal accessory (XI) nerves and the internal jugular vein (IJV). 

The foramen is divided into two parts by a fibro-osseous bridge connecting the jugular spine of the temporal bone and jugular process of the occipital bone.

  1. The anteromedial compartment (pars nervosa) contains the cranial nerve IX, the tympanic branch of IX (Jacobson's nerve), and the inferior petrosal sinus.
  2. The posterolateral component (pars venosa or vascularis) contains the IJV, jugular bulb, cranial nerves X and XI, the auricular branch of vagus (Arnold's nerve), and the posterior meningeal branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery.

The jugular foramen syndrome (JFS or Vernet syndrome) refers to paralysis of the IX, X, and XI cranial nerves traversing the jugular foramen.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the hospital due to right arm weakness. The patient injured his right shoulder several months ago in an accident and has had difficulty elevating his arm since. On examination, there is diminished pinprick and temperature sensation over a small area in the right upper lateral arm and prominent atrophy of the right deltoid. Reflexes and hand grip strength are normal in the upper extremities bilaterally. This patient most likely injured which of the following nerves
questions.solution: Axillary nerve supplies the deltoid and teres minor muscles. Deltoid muscle helps in abduction of arm from 15 to 90 degrees. Axillary nerve also supplies the skin on upper lateral side of arm.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the clinic with a 3-week history of difficulty hearing. He finds it increasingly difficult to tolerate everyday sounds. He also complains of ear pain and often avoids public places as a result. The patient has no past medical history and takes no medications. Injury to which of the following cranial nerves is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution: • The presentation indicates compromised stapedial reflex and the cranial nerve which supplies to stapedius muscle is facial nerve.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man fractures his right tibia in a motor vehicle accident. His right leg is fixed in a cast and he requires underarm crutches to ambulate. Two weeks later, he comes to the clinic with right upper-extremity weakness and numbness. He has no neck or arm pain. The patient is concerned because he is right-handed and cannot perform his duties as an electrician. On neurologic examination, there is diminished strength on extension of the right wrist with an absent triceps reflex. Injury to which of the following nerves is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: • Nerve involved in Crutch Palsy is Radial Nerve. Radial nerve supplies to posterior compartment of arm (Triceps muscles) and Posterior compartment of forearm ( Extensor muscles ).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he suddenly became unresponsive at home. On arrival, he was found pulseless with ventricular fibrillation. After 10 minutes of CPR, the patient regains spontaneous circulation. In the hospital, he is intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. His vitals remain stable. A therapeutic hypothermia protocol is initiated. After 72 hours following rewarming, he remains comatosed with fixed and dilated pupils. There is no direct or consensual pupillary response to light. Damage to which of the following areas of the brain is the most likely cause of this patient's pupillary findings?
questions.solution: • The Edinger–Westphal nucleus (accessory oculomotor nucleus) is the parasympathetic subnucleus that innervates the sphincter pupillae muscle and the ciliaris muscle. Loss of pupillary reflex is due to involvement of Edinger westphal nucleus, which is located in the midbrain.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the office due to several weeks of pain and muffled hearing in the left ear. She also describes a sensation of jaw clicking when chewing food. The patient has a background history of episodic headaches and left-sided facial pain for several years that are worse when moving the jaw. She also has been told that she grinds her teeth while asleep. On examination, the patient is unable to open her mouth fully and develops pain with passive movement of the jaw. The external auditory canal and tympanic membrane are normal. Rinne and Weber tests are also normal. Left medial pterygoid muscle dysfunction is suspected. Involvement of which of the following nerves is most likely causing this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: • All the muscles of mastication (Masseter, temporalis, Lateral pterygoid and Medial Pterygoid muscles) are supplied by Mandibular nerve (branch of Trigeminal Nerve).

questions.text: A 26-year-old previously healthy man is brought to the emergency department following a motorbike accident. He is found to have a maxillofacial injury. His condition is stabilized, and surgical repair is performed. While recovering, the patient develops difficulty chewing food. On examination, the jaw deviates to the right side when the patient is instructed to open his mouth. The nerve that has been injured in this patient exits the skull through which of the following foramina
questions.solution: • Condition explained here indicates the involvement of Mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve and it passes through Foramen Ovale.

questions.text: A highly agitated 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his family because he is unable to effectively communicate. questions.solution: • Middle cerebral artery is the chief artery supplying the superolateral surface of cerebral hemisphere, which consists of speech areas (Broca's and Wernicke's).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is evaluated in the clinic due to worsening lower extremity pain and weakness. questions.text: All are treatment modalities for sudden sensorineural hearing loss except:
questions.solution:
The most common treatment modalities for ISSHL are one or more of the following: systemic steroids (SSs), intratympanic steroid injection (ITSI), hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HOT), antiviral drugs, and vasodilators or vasoactive substances.

Some cases will improve spontaneously. Transdermal nitroglycerin patch along with pulse steroid injections are the most recent form of treatment being studied and may provide hope for these patients, despite of the rarity and the unpredictable natural history of the disorder.

questions.text: Identify the area marked with the arrow?
What is the wavelength of CO2 laser?
questions.solution: The CO2 laser emits invisible infrared light at a wavelength of 10,600 nm in the infrared range of the electromagnetic spectrum, and the light cannot be seen by the human eye. Carbon-dioxide (CO2) lasers are powerful and comparatively efficient gas lasers emitting at 10.6 µm or at other wavelengths around 9-11 µm. A gas discharge excites nitrogen molecules, which transfer their energy to the laser-active CO2 molecules.

questions.text: Which of the following tuning fork test is used to check Malingering ?
questions.solution: The Stenger test is based on the auditory phenomenon “The Stenger Principle” and is used when a patient is suspected malingering a hearing loss. The Stenger Principle states that only the louder of two similar tones presented to both ears at the same time will be perceived.

questions.text: All are indications of Myringotomy except?
questions.solution:
A myringotomy, sometimes called by other names, is a surgical procedure in which a tiny incision is created in the eardrum (tympanic membrane) to relieve pressure caused by excessive buildup of fluid, or to drain pus from the middle ear.

Incision types

Myringotomy is usually performed as an outpatient procedure.

Cutting type: given in posterior inferior quadrant, this is done in cases of acute otitis media.

Splitting type: given in anterior inferior quadrant, this is done in cases of serious otitis media ('glue ear'), this type of incision is suitable for grommet insertion.

Incision is either 'j'(hockey) shaped or curvilinear shaped and it is given from below upward so as to ease the drainage

A myringotomy may be done: To restore hearing loss caused by chronic fluid build-up and to prevent delayed speech development caused by hearing loss in children. To place tympanostomy tubes — these tubes help to equalize pressure.

questions.text: Which is the most preferred modality of treatment for recurrent respiratory papillomatosis?
questions.solution:
The current standard of care for the management of RRP is surgical excision. Objectives of surgery are to preserve adequate voice quality and airway patency.36 Complete eradication is not necessarily the goal, as HPV is believed to remain dormant in laryngeal epithelial cells whether active papilloma is visible or not. More extensive excision of papilloma from sites that are not contributing to airway or voice?related goals has not been shown to reduce recurrence rates.37 In fact, aggressive resection may be counter?productive, in that injury to the mucosal surface has been associated with increased expression of HPV in nearby HPV?infected cells.

In addition,two pilot studies showed preliminary evidencefor post? excision,office? based,intralesional administration of the adjuvants bevacizumab and cidofovir improving the outcome

In this question

Accidental pregnancies= 2

So PI= 2x4=8/HWY

questions.text: Which of the following is strategy for eradication of Poliomyelitis?
questions.solution:
Different strategies for eradication of polio are based on epidemiology of poliomyelitis and characteristics of polio vaccines. In case of poliomyelitis there is only one clinical case for 100 or 100 inapparent infections. Therefore polio eradication strategies involve universal immunization. Various strategies for eradication of polio are-

a) Routine Immunization

b) Supplementary Immunization

c) Enhanced surveillance of Acute Flaccid Paralysis

d) Targeted mop-up campaigns

questions.text: For a 60kg Indian male, minimum daily protein requirement has been calculated to be 40gm ±10 (SD). RDA of protein would be
questions.solution:
The recommended dietary allowance (RDA) is the average daily dietary intake level that suffices to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97–98%) healthy persons of a specific sex, age, life stage, or physiological condition (such as pregnancy or lactation).               

 RDA is defined as two standard deviations above the average  requirement, assuming that the distribution of nutrient requirements is normal

So RDA is Mean+ 2 SD for all nutrients except for energy

questions.text: Regarding term 'Delivery Points' in RMNCH+A which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
• The provision of services for delivery care in a health facility generally serves as an important indicator to assess whether the facility is optimally functional or not. The concept of 'delivery point' emerges from this presumption.
  • Among the health facilities designated as Ll, L2 and L3, there are some facilities which are conducting deliveries above a minimum bench mark (minimum 3 normal deliveries per month at Ll; minimum 10 deliveries per month, including management of complications, at L2; minimum 20-50 deliveries per month including C-section at L3).
  • These are designated as delivery points.
  • According to the government mandate, these facilities should be the first to be strengthened for providing comprehensive RMNCH Services.
  • This should be supported by a referral transport system that reaches the patient within 30 minutes of receiving a call and the health facility within the next 30 minutes.

questions.text: Which of The Following Is Not Criteria For Polio Free Certification
questions.solution:
As per WHO policy only a WHO region, and not any individual country, will be certified as polio free. Criteria for certification of any region as polio free requires

1) All countries of the region should maintain polio free status for at least 3 consecutive years.

2) Absence of wild polio virus from the communities as indicated by stool samples from normal children and where appropriate from waste water from high risk populations

 3) Appropriate measures established to deal with importations

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy with 2 episodes pf pneumonia in last 3 months is evaluated and found to have a wide-fixed split S2. His Echocardiograhy reveals a moderate-sized ostium secundum ASD with Qp:Qs ratio of 2.5:1. What is the management recommended in this child?
questions.solution: Transcatheter device or surgical closure is advised for all symptomatic ASD patients, as well as for asymptomatic patients with Qp:Qs ratio of at least 2 : 1 and those with RV enlargement. The timing for elective closure is usually after the 1st yr of life and before entry into school. For most patients, the procedure of choice is percutaneous catheter device closure using an atrial septal occlusion device, implanted transvenously in the cardiac catheterization laboratory.

questions.text: A child develops a rash on face as shown in the picture. There was no fever and the rash responded to topical corticosteroids. His mother is having history of bronchial asthma. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: This is the typical presentation of childhood atopic dermatitis, also called eczema which has a strong familial clustering. Fifth disease presents with fever followed by rash producing a slapped cheek appearance. Sixth disease will have high grade fever for a few days, followed by rash appearing after fever subsides, mainly on the trunk. None of the other options will have a positive family history.

questions.text: Which of the following is the immediate therapy of choice in a child presenting with septic shock, according to Sepsis-2020 Guidelines?
questions.solution:
As per Sepsis-2020 Guidelines for Pediatric septic shock

  • Start IV Fluid Boluses in case of hypotension
  • Balanced/Buffered Crystalloids preferred over 0.9% Saline
    i.e. Ringer’s Lactate is preferred over Normal Saline
  • Amount: 40-60 ml/kg in the first hour of management, given as 10-20 ml/kg boluses
  • If the care center does not have an ICU (e.g. PHC), give only 40 ml/kg maximum fluid
  • Avoid colloids like Albumin.
  • Although antibiotics should be started early, one should not wait for culture report and can be given in first hour, after fluid resuscitation has been started

questions.text: A lady treated with ovulation induction drugs for infertility comes with abdominal pain, loss of appetite & difficulty in breathing clinical examination reveals tense ascites. Investigations reveals large hydrothorax with hematocrit of 60%. Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Classification

Mild:

  • Abdomen bloating
  • Mild pain abdomen
  • Ovarian size <8cm2
  • Severe:
  • Clinical ascites +/- hydrothorax
  • Oliguria <300 ml/d or < 30ml/hr
  • Hematocrit >0.45
  • Hyponatremia sodium <135mmol/L
  • Hypoosmolality <282 mosm/kg
  • Hyperkalemia (K+ >5mmol/L)
  • Hypoproteinemia (Albumin <35g/L)
  • Ovarian size >12cm2
  • Creat >1.2
  • Creat clearance <50ml/mt
  • Increased liver enzyme

Moderate:

  • Moderate abdomen pain
  • Nausea, Vomiting
  • USG shows ascites
  • Ovarian size 8~12cm2

Critical:

  • Tense ascites
  • Large hydrothorax
  • Hematocit > 0.45
  • WBC > 25,000/mL
  • Anuria
  • Thromboembolism
  • ARDS

questions.text: A patient is referred to you by your Physician colleague asking for your opinion regarding starting Bupropion for smoking cessation. Which of the following is NOT a matter of concern in starting Bupropion?

Bupropion is an antidepressant which belongs to the class of Nor epinephrine Dopamine Reuptake inhibitor. It also has non-competitive antagonism at Nicotinic Acetylcholine receptors which makes it useful in Smoking cessation, along with its Dopamine elevation properties.

Risk of exacerbation of Psychosis and seizures make it less preferred in choice A and B, and adverse effects of Tremor, Insomnia, Nausea, Decreased appetite and weight loss makes it less preferred in option C. However, it does not cause sedation, does not affect sexual function. In fact, it is added to or cross tapered to, when a patient on SSRI develops sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: An adult patient presents with chronically pruritic skin with scaly, plaque-like eruptions on the knees, elbows and gluteal cleft along with intense dandruff on scalp. He has also noticed "potholes" in his fingernails bilaterally. On review of systems, he also notes early-morning back pain, which improves with movement. When considering possible treatment regimens for this patient, which of these is the best drug to use?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate

  • The skin, scalp and nail lesion favour a diagnosis of psoriasis associated with psoriatic spondylitis.
  • Psoriasis is a common chronic inflammatory skin disease.
  • It is characterized by erythematous, sharply demarcated papules and rounded plaques covered by a silvery scale.
  • Although psoriasis is classically a non prutitic disorder, it may be associated with pruritic in a quarter of patients.
  • Traumatized areas often develop lesions (Koebner phenomenon). Infections, stress, and medications may exacerbate psoriasis.
  • Fingernail lesions such as pitting, onycholysis, or nail thickening or subungual hyperkeratosis are present in 50% of patients.
  • Topical treatment options for psoriasis include mid-potency glucocorticoids, vitamin D analogues, retinoids, and ultraviolet light.
  • Systemic therapy is reserved for severe or widespread disease.
  • Oral glucocorticoids should not be used for the treatment of psoriasis due to the life-threatening risk of developing pustular psoriasis when therapy is discontinued.
  • Systemic therapies include methotrexate, retinoids, calcineurin inhibitors, hydroxyurea and biologic agents .
  • Methotrexate is the drug of choice for extensive chronic plaque psoriasis + ps arthritis

questions.text: Which of the following attitude will be seen in a patient with posterior dislocation of hip?
questions.solution:
• Dislocations are usually posterior, and occasionally anterior, or central through the acetabulum.
  • Posterior Dislocation: Hip is flexed, adducted, and internally rotated, and leg is shortened.
  • Anterior Dislocation: Hip is flexed, abducted, and externally rotated, and leg is shortened.
  • Central Dislocation: Trochanter is displaced medially. One may be able to feel the head of femur rectally. There is no shortening.

questions.text: Which part of scaphoid fracture is most susceptible to avascular necrosis?
questions.solution:
• Scaphoid fractures (i.e. fractures through the scaphoid bone) are common, in some instances can be difficult to diagnose, and can result in significant functional impairment.
  • Epidemiology
  • Scaphoid fractures account for 70-80% of all carpal bone fractures.
  • Although they occur essentially at any age, adolescents and young adults are most commonly affected.
  • Older patients falling in a similar manner are more likely to sustain a distal radial fracture (usually a Colles fracture).
  • Clinical Presentation
  • Classically there can be pain in anatomical snuffbox which is thought to have a sensitivity of ~90% and a specificity ~40%
  • Fractures can occur essentially anywhere along the scaphoid, but distribution is not even:
  • waist of scaphoid: 70-80%
  • proximal pole: 20%
  • distal pole (or so-called scaphoid tubercle): 10%

Treatment

  • Classically, treatment is with curettage and packing with bone chips or polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA).

questions.text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple hypermetropic astigmatism?
questions.solution:
Simple hypermetropic astigmatism is when one focal line is on the retina and the other focal line is focussed behind the retina. This means that there is only a plus cylinder needed for the correction of astigmatism.

Option D is Simple hypermetropic astigmatism. Also, in the option D, plus cylinder is at 180 degrees which means the horizontal meridian is flat. Therefore, it is Against-the-rule astigmatism(horizontal steep and vertical flat)

Option A is incomplete. Any cylinder without its axis is irrelevant and incomplete

Option B is simple myopic astigmatism. Here, the minus cylinder is at 180 degrees which means the horizontal meridian is flat. Therefore, it is With-the-rule astigmatism(vertical meridian is steep and horizontal meridian is flat)

Option C has only spherical correction(minus sphere). It is myopia

questions.text: The given fundus image shows:
questions.solution:
Drusen are the hallmark of dry AMD(Age-related Macular Degeneration)
Based on their size:

  • Small drusen (“drupelets”) are less than 63?µm in diameter
  • Intermediate drusen are 63 to 125?µm
  • Large drusen are greater than 125?µm.

Small drusen are considered normal aging and do not represent a risk for progression to advanced AMD.

AMD has been categorized by The Age-Related Eye Disease Study (AREDS) based on exam findings of hard drusen, soft drusen, RPE abnormalities, atrophy, and choroidal neovascularization.
The AREDS categories are as follows:

Category 1 (No AMD): 

  • No drusen or
  • A few (5-15) small (<63µm) drusen without pigment changes

Category 2 (Early AMD): Several small drusen, few intermediate-sized (63-124µm) drusen,
and/or pigmentary changes in one or both eyes

Category 3 (Intermediate AMD): Extensive intermediate-sized drusen, one large (>125µm)
druse, and/or geographic atrophy not involving the macula in one or both eyes

Category 4 (Advanced unilateral AMD): Advanced dry form (i.e., macula-involving geographic
atrophy) or exudative form with choroidal neovascularization in one eye


Category 4a: Advanced AMD in one eye with category 1, 2, or 3 AMD in the fellow eye


Category 4b: Advanced AMD in one eye and decreased visual acuity (<20/32) secondary to AMD in the fellow eye; however, advanced AMD is not present in both eyes

questions.text: A 52-year old female patient being treated for rheumatoid arthritis presents to eye OPD with complaints of bilateral decrease in vision. She has no other comorbidities. Fundus was examined and the FAF images of both the eyes are shown below. Identify the false statement regarding her condition:
questions.solution:
This is a patient with Hydroxychloroquine toxicity.

Recommended dose of HCQ: Maximum daily HCQ use of <5.0 mg/kg real weight, which correlates better with risk than ideal weight.
Risk of Toxicity: The risk of toxicity is dependent on daily dose and duration of use. At recommended doses, the risk of toxicity up to 5 years is under 1% and up to 10 years is under 2%, but it rises to almost 20% after 20 years. However, even after 20 years, a patient without toxicity has only a 4% risk of converting in the subsequent year.

The primary screening tests are:

Automated visual fields plus spectral-domain optical coherence tomography(SD OCT)
SD OCT shows localized thinning of the photoreceptor layers in the parafoveal region. These localized areas of photoreceptor loss are strong indicators of toxicity. Initial damage sometimes can be recognized as distinct focal interruption of the photoreceptor outer segment structural lines
MfERG, Fundus Autofluorescence(FAF) imaging are additional screening tests that may be done when available or as needed.

FAF reveals:
. Early parafoveal or extramacular photoreceptor damage as an area of increased autofluorescence(seen in the image) that may precede thinning on SD OCT.
. Late RPE loss appears as a dark area of reduced autofluorescence
RISK FACTORS for HCQ toxicity:



Lesser risk factors:
- Age
- Liver disease
? Genetics – ABCA4 pOlymorphisms

questions.text: Zepto is used to:
questions.solution:
Zepto (trade name)  is a novel capsulotomy technology called precision pulse capsulotomy (PPC). It is an FDA-approved disposable capsulotomy device that uses highly focused, quick, multi-pulse, low electrical energy discharge to produce a perfectly round anterior capsulotomy instantaneously uniformly along 360. It works independent of pupil size, corneal clarity, or lens density. This can be done during the normal sequence of the cataract surgery
Electrical nano-pulses are delivered to a nitinol (Nickel-Titanium) ring to create the capsulotomy instantaneously and simultaneously along all 360°, with no cautery or burning of tissue. Vaporization of water molecules trapped between the capsule and nitinol edge causes the stretched capsular membrane to split circumferentially all at once.

questions.text: Outer blood retinal barrier is formed by which layer?
questions.solution:
Outer blood retinal barrier is formed by tight juctions between the RPE cells.(D in the image)
Inner blood retinal barrier is formed by the tight junctions between the endothelial cells of the retinal capillaries
In the image of retinal layers:

  1. Ganglion cell layer
  2. Inner nuclear layer(containing cell bodies and nuclei of bipolar cells, horizontal cells, amacrine cells and Muller cells)
  3. Outer nuclear layer(containing cell bodies and nuclei of photoreceptors)
  4. Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE)

Functions of RPE:

  1. Outer blood retinal barrier
  2. Prevents backscatter of incident light
  3. Phagocytosis of outersegments shed by photoreceptors
  4. Recycling of Vitamin A
  5. Pumping out of fluid from the subretinal space

questions.text: From the general examination finding of this patient 40 year old female admitted in the medicine ward, what is the likely nutrient deficiency that the patient is having ?
questions.solution:
The patient in question is having perifollicular hemorrhages and cork screw shaped hair suggestive of Scurvy (Vitamin C deficiency). Dear students, have a look at the following images showing the mucocutaneous manifestations of scurvy.

Physical examination of the legs in the above image is showing perifollicular petechiae, follicular hyperkeratosis, and corkscrew hairs in addition to red and blue ecchymoses on both ankles (Panels A and B). Examination of the oral mucosa showed gingival bleeding (Panel C). A skin-biopsy from the lesion on one leg shows a corkscrew hair (Panel D, arrow) with perifollicular hemorrhage

questions.text: The following is the ECG of a patient done as a part of routine work up before a major surgery. Seeing the abnormality, a medicine consultation is done to comment on this ECG. What is the likely explanation the medicine consultant has for the ECG finding ?
questions.solution: The ECG finding is that of Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). LBBB may be a finding in ischemic heart disease, cardiomyopathy and hypertensive heart disease.

questions.text: Which of the findings does not favor pre-renal azotemia ?
questions.solution: In pre-renal azotemia, Fractional excretion of sodium is <1%

questions.text: The following is the ECG of a patient who presented with acute onset breathless to the emergency. What is the confirmatory test for the diagnosis of the patient ?
questions.solution: The ECG is showing electrical alternans. Electrical alternans, i.e. alternating QRS voltage, is a specific but insensitive ECG finding of a large pericardial effusion with tamponade. It is caused by mechanical anterior–posterior swinging of the heart in the large fluid. Echo will help to confirm the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.

choices.text: MRI of the brain with contrast

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents to the emergency department with leg weakness, falls, and numbness, which have progressively worsened over the last week. She has been unable to control her bladder and had several episodes of incontinence. Her neurological examination reveals nearly flaccid paralysis of her legs and loss of sensation in her legs to all modalities. She has sensation loss to vibration and pin prick in her hands, and strength is mildly reduced. Her MRI is shown. Which of the following tests would uncover the diagnosis?
questions.solution: This patient presents with a severe transverse myelitis as evidenced by lower extremity paralysis and sensory loss to all modalities. MRIs show a longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM), spanning ≥3 spinal levels. LETM should point toward the diagnosis of neuromyelitis optica (NMO), and frequently aquaporin-4 antibodies are found in these patients. Oligoclonal bands can point toward a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS), which is possible, but myelitis in MS is usually a small segment or partial segment of the cord, not a longitudinally extensive lesion.

questions.text: The below Chest Xray is that of a 58 year old chronic alcoholic who is admitted in the medicine ICU as a case of pneumonia. What is the likely causative organism ?
questions.solution: The X-ray shows the Bulging fissure sign. The bulging fissure sign refers to lobar consolidation where the affected portion of the lung is expanded causing displacement of the adjacent fissure.This is often associated with klebsiella pneumonia.

questions.text: The below is the diagrammatic representation of the breathing pattern of a patient admitted in the medicine ICU with an acute onset breathlessness following chest pain. What is the pattern of respiration here ?
questions.solution: This is the classical Cheyne Stokes respiration. Its also referred to as waxing and waning type of respiration. It is seen in acute LVF, raised ICT and Narcotic poisoning. The patient in question is probably having acute left ventricular failure following an acute coronary event.

questions.text: The following image is the Diffusion weighted MRI sequence of a patient who was admitted in the neurology ICU following a stroke. What is the likely finding in this patient ?
questions.solution: The Diffusion sequence is showing hyperintensity in the region of left occipital lobe extending into the splenium of corpus callosum. This is the classical site of lesion producing pure alexia (alexia without agraphia)

questions.text: A 54 year old female presented with cough and dyspnea of 4 years duration. She has a past history of anterior uveitis. The physician also noticed the following general examination finding. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Skin involvement is eventually identified in over a third of patients with sarcoidosis. The classic cutaneous lesions include erythema nodosum, maculopapular lesions, hyper- and hypopigmentation, keloid formation, and subcutaneous nodules. A specific complex of involvement of the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks is referred to as lupus pernio and is diagnostic for a chronic form of sarcoidosis.

questions.text: The image below shows the urine examination finding in a 45 year old male admitted to the nephrology ward. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution: The presence of 'muddy brown casts' of epithelial cells found in the urine during urinalysis is pathognomonic for Acute tubular necrosis.

questions.text: The following general examination findings were noticed in a 40 year old male who presented to the OPD. What is the likely enzymatic defect ?
questions.solution: Ochronosis is a rare disorder which manifests as a bluish-black discoloration of the skin and mucosa. It occurs due to deficiency of an enzyme homogentisic acid oxidase.

questions.text: The image shows the endoscopic picture of a 73 year old male admitted for evaluation of GI bleeding. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) syndrome, also known as watermelon stomach is a significant cause of acute or chronic gastrointestinal blood loss in the elderly. is characterized endoscopically by 'watermelon stripes.'

questions.text: The following image shows the sputum study of a 45 year old female admitted in the medicine ward with a chronic respiratory problem. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution: The sputum in the image shows Curschmann’s spirals . In bronchial asthma, the mucus plugs contain whorls of shed epithelium, which give rise to the well-known spiral shaped mucus plugs called Curschmann spirals

questions.text: A 16 year old boy was referred to a tertiary Haematology centre as a case of bone marrow failure syndrome. The haematologist makes an observation of the following findings in the image. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Dyskeratosis congenita is an inherited bone marrow failure syndrome characterized clinically by the triad of abnormal nails, reticular skin pigmentation, and oral leukoplakia, and associated with very high risks of developing aplastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndrome, leukemia, and solid tumors. Some features typically appear in childhood. But pulmonary fibrosis and liver cirrhosis typically present in adulthood. The image in question shows the characteristic triad.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presented with unilateral ptosis with no other symptoms. Application of an ice pack to the left eye improved his symptom. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: The ice-pack test can be a useful bedside test to distinguish myasthenia gravis from other causes of ptosis or ophthalmoparesis. The inhibition of acetylcholinesterase activity at a reduced muscle temperature is thought to underlie the observed clinical improvement.

questions.text: An 86-year-old man came to the medicine OPD as a part of the follow up visit for coronary artery disease. The consultant on general examination of the patient noticed an absent right pectoralis major muscle and brachydactyly of the right hand since birth. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Poland syndrome is characterized by partial or complete absence of pectoral muscles , most commonly unilateral. This may be associated with aplasia or hypoplasia of other chest wall muscles. Most patients do not have any respiratory symptoms. Brachydactyly and syndactyly may often be associated.

questions.text: A 40 -year-old man was referred to a tertiary care hospital with with progressive neutropenia and anemia . Bone marrow aspiration was done and the slide image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The bone marrow aspirate shows myeloblast with auer rods. Auer rods are pink or red-stained needle-shaped structures seen in the cytoplasm of myeloid cells, containing agglomeration of azurophilic granules. This is most likely a case of AML M3.

In AML, the neoplastic cells are blocked at an early stage of myeloid cell development. Immature myeloid cells (blasts) accumulate in the marrow and replace normal elements and frequently circulate in peripheral blood. By definition, in AML, myeloid blasts or promyelocytes make up more than 20% of the bone marrow cellular component.

questions.text: The given ECG trace is that of a patient admitted in ICU. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution: The ECG finding of a positive deflection at the J point (negative in aVR and V1) with a dome or hump configuration is most frequently termed a J wave or Osborn wave. There is no definitive physiological cause for the deflection despite numerous postulates. Broad differential diagnosis of prominent Osborn waves including hypothermia; benign early repolarization; hypercalcaemia and the Brugada syndrome.

questions.text: The pulse tracing shown below is most likely that of a patient with :
questions.solution: Pulsus alternans (alternation of one strong and one weak beat without a change in the cycle length) occurs most commonly in left ventricular failure.

choices.text: Magnetic resonance angiogram of the neck

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency room with 1 day of headache and several hours of left arm heaviness. He fell off a ladder and hurt his neck the day before. In completing a full neurological examination, the emergency room physician additionally notes the abnormality shown here. Which of the following is the most likely test to demonstrate the etiology of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Given the history of recent trauma, the most likely cause of this patient’s left arm weakness and right Horner syndrome is right carotid artery dissection. The sympathetic chain runs inside the carotid sheath in the neck and, in the case of cervical carotid dissection, may cause an ipsilateral Horner syndrome with contralateral symptoms of anterior circulation stroke. So MRA can be used to visualise the dissection. 

CT/MRI of the brain may demonstrate evidence of ischemia related to the carotid dissection, but would not be the most direct means of diagnosing the problem. Chest x-ray would be a reasonable test to look for a Pancoast tumor, which may cause ipsilateral Horner syndrome. However, in the event that the brachial plexus were also affected by a Pancoast tumor, the weakness would also be ipsilateral. Further, the recent trauma in this patient reduces the likelihood of a tumor. Electroencephalogram would not be a useful test in this patient, because seizure would be quite unlikely to cause Horner syndrome.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presents with right-sided weakness. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of his computed tomography scan findings?
questions.solution: The basal ganglia is a common location for primary intracerebral hemorrhage related to hypertension, which accounts for up to 10% of all strokes. Other common sites of hemorrhage include the pons, thalamus, cerebellum, and the deep subcortical structures. Pathologically, hypertension-related primary intracranial hemorrhages occur because of lipohyalinosis of the deep perforating arteries, which makes these small vessels highly sensitive to sudden changes in blood pressure. Venous sinus thrombosis can certainly lead to hemorrhage, but typically occurs in the territory of a draining vein. Atrial fibrillation could lead to hemorrhage, but most often is a secondary phenomenon after ischemia occurs. Amyloid angiopathy leads to amyloid deposition and microhemorrhages usually in the cortical regions of the brain (rather than the subcortical as in this case)

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is evaluated for loss of milestones. On examination, he is less than 2nd percentile for height, and in the 80th percentile for weight. He has hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facies, corneal clouding, macroglossia, and decreased hearing bilaterally. A female cousin had similar symptoms. His image is shown here. Which of the following is the deficient enzyme?
questions.solution: The child described in the question has Hurler syndrome, also known as mucopolysaccharidosis type 1 (MPS I), which is an autosomal-recessive disease causing a deficiency in alpha-L iduronidase and resultant accumulation of glycosaminoglycans. This disease may be treated with bone marrow transplantation or with enzyme replacement.

questions.text: A 24 year old male was admitted with uncontrolled hypertension. Examination showed diminished lower limb pulsations. The Chest X-ray finding is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution: The X-ray shows inferior rib notching. Often the associated condition is co-arctation of aorta. It can present with uncontrolled hypertension and diminished lower limb pulsations. There will also be disparity in the blood pressure of upper and lower extremities.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presented with reddish brown rash in his groin. Wood's lamp examination showed a pattern of fluorescence shown in image. What is your diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Illumination of the plaque with a Wood's lamp, which emits ultraviolet A radiation, revealed a brilliant, coral-red fluorescence, characteristic of the porphyrin pigments produced by Corynebacterium minutissimum in erythrasma.

questions.text: What is the name of the technique used in the treatment of perforator incompetence?
questions.solution: The Tessari method is the one most often used to foam detergent sclerosants. A syringe of liquid sclerosant is connected to a syringe of air by a three-way stopcock valve. The stopcock valve is turned 30-45º from its flat position to make the foamed bubbles as small as possible while still allowing the two syringes to mix. The syringes are mixed vigorously back and forth at least 20 times.

questions.text:
A 55-year old male patient who is an asthmatic had undergone laparotomy for intestinal obstruction. On post-op day 3, his blood pressure was 90/60mm Hg, pulse was 110/min, urine output was adequate, had passed stool 4 times and peripheries were warm. Surgeon orders ABG report which is as follows:

pH of 7.35, PaO2 of76mmHg, mixed venous saturation of 75%, base deficit is high. What is the most likely cause for this patient’s findings?
questions.solution:
Option A: Findings that suggest this patient could be in septic shock are:

  • Blood pressure and pulse are altered(BP low and pulse rate increased)
  • Warm peripheries
  • Mixed venous oxygen saturation of 75%
  • High Base deficit

 Option B: Arrythmia can produce cardiogenic shock but in it, peripheries would be cold and mixed venous oxygen saturation would be low

 Option C:Tension pneumothorax produces obstructive shock but again in it, mixed venous oxygen saturation would be low and peripheries would be cold.

 Option D:Diarrhea would lead to hypovolemic shock but in it, peripheries would  be cold and mixed venous oxygen saturation would be low.



 Reference: Bailey and love 27th Edition chapter 2: page no. 14

In case of cyst rupture, anaphylactic shock may develop

questions.text: A 14-year old girl presented with pain over right upper abdomen and rash over abdomen. With antihistaminics, the rash disappears but pain persists even after the use of painkillers. CT abdomen was done which is shown in the image below. All of the following statements are correct except:
questions.solution:
This is a case of hydatid cyst.

      Option A: CT scan shows type I hydatid cyst. The three layers of hydatid cyst are:

  1. Inner endocyst that contain germinal membrane
  2. Intermediate ectocyst and
  3. Outer pericyst; pericyst is derived from compressed host organ tissue

 Option B: Due to the high antigenicity of hydatid fluid, patients develop severe anaphylactic shock  if the cyst ruptures

Option C: Casoni skin test has an immediate type I hypersensitivity  reaction that is read within 30 minutes of the intradermal injection and a type IV hypersensitivity reaction that is read after 18-24 hours.

 Option D: PAIR (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection and Reaspiration) would be ideal as there is no much septation and it is less invasive.

Reference: Bailey and Love chapter 6

questions.text: Mr. X was hospitalized due to burns. He was on complete bedrest. He was administered intravenously 3litres of fluids containing 20% dextrose and 4.0% protein in a day. His weight is 60 kg. Identify the correct statement regarding this clinical scenario:
questions.solution:
Energy gained from the fluids

                                   = 3L solution (20% dextrose + 4.0% protein)

                                   = 600 g dextrose  + 120g protein

                                   = 2400kcal + 480kCal

(1g carbohydrate=4 kcal, 1 g fat= 9 kcal, 1 g protein= 4 kcal)

                                   = 2880kcal supplied

In patients with burns, energy requirement is in the range of 40kcal/kg/day

                                  =40*60 = 2400 kcal is required

Protein supply in this patient:

                                   = 3L solution with 4.0% protein

                                   = 120 g protein supplied

In trauma or critical illness, the protein requirement is in the range of  1.5-2 g/kg/day. i.e. 90-120g/day of protein is required

 Therefore, in this patient,  energy supplied is 2880kCal(against a requirement of 2400kCal/day) and the protein supply is 120g(against a  requirement of 90-120 g/day). So, both energy and protein are adequately supplied.                       

Reference: Bailey and love chapter 19 page no 282; Schwartz 11th edition chapter 2 page no 68

questions.text: A 50-year old male patient was hit by a car while walking and was thrown across the road. He presented to casualty with head injury. His GCS score is E2V2M4. After the accident he regained consciousness immediately but started losing consciousness after some time. CT-head is given below. What would be the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Here, the patient has GCS score of 8 and is losing consciousness further.

The CT-head  shows a large extradural hematoma on  the left side with a midline shift. So, this patient ideally should be treated with open craniotomy and hematoma evacuation urgently as extradural hematoma has higher chances of survival if operated earlier.

 Indications for craniotomy in extradural hematoma are:

  1. Volume of hematoma >30cm3
  2. >5 mm midline shift
  3. Deteriorating patients
  4. Comatose patients
  5. Associated with focal neurological deficits
  6. Hematoma thickness >15mm

 Reference: Bailey and love 27th edition chapter 24 page no 334.

 Greenberg Handbook of neurosurgery page no 863

questions.text: A 56-year old female presented with a swelling in lower abdomen. On further investigation, a diagnosis of femoral hernia was made. The surgeon planned a laparoscopic surgery for the same. On inserting the laparoscope, the following structures were seen as shown in the image. Identify the structure A marked in the image.
questions.solution:
A – Inguinal ligament

B – Lacunar ligament

C-Arch of pubic bone

D – Fatty tissue overlying iliac vessels

Option A. and B.  They are enclosed in a fibrous sheath. Just medial to the vein is a small space containing fat and some lymphatic tissue (node of Cloquet). It is this space which is exploited by a femoral hernia. The walls of a femoral hernia are the femoral vein laterally, the inguinal ligament anteriorly, the pelvic bone covered by the iliopectineal ligament (Astley Cooper’s) posteriorly and the lacunar ligament (Gimbernat’s) medially. This is a strong curved ligament with a sharp unyielding edge which impedes reduction of a femoral hernia.

 Option D. The iliac artery and vein pass below the inguinal ligament to become the femoral vessels in the leg. The vein lies medially and the artery just lateral to the artery with the femoral nerve lateral to the artery.

 Reference : Bailey And Love 27th Edition Pg. 1035

questions.text:
A 26 year old male patient presented to the OPD with history of blood in vomitus. He has history of intake of alcohol following which he had forceful vomiting and later had an episode of hematemesis. On examination, his pulse was 90/min, blood pressure was 132/78 mm Hg. He was conscious and oriented. On investigation, his Hb was 10.4 g% and other parameters were within normal limits. Consider the following statements with regards to the etiology of his bleed.
1. The condition causes a mucosal tear at the cardia rather than a full-thickness perforation
2. The split in the mucosa is usually horizontal
3. Intramural rupture and intramural hematoma can be differential diagnosis but are less likely in this patient
4. Endoscopic therapy is usually required for management of most cases of bleeding
questions.solution:
Statement 1: Forceful vomiting may produce a mucosal tear at the cardia rather than a full-thickness perforation. The mechanism of injury is different. In Boerhaave’s syndrome, vomiting occurs against a closed glottis and pressure builds up in the oesophagus.

Statement 2: In Mallory–Weiss syndrome, vigorous vomiting produces a vertical split in the gastric mucosa, immediately below the squamocolumnar junction at the cardia in 90% of cases. In only 10%, the tear is in the oesophagus.

Statement 3: There are two other injuries to the oesophagus that lie within the spectrum of the mucosal tear of Mallory–Weiss and the full-thickness tear of Boerhaave. Intramural rupture produces a dissection within the esophageal wall that causes severe chest pain, often with odynophagia. It is best diagnosed by contrast radiology. Intramural hematoma is most often seen in elderly patients on anticoagulants or patients with coagulation disorders, and usually follows an episode of vomiting.

Large hematomas causing dysphagia can occur, extending from the cardia up to the carina. The diagnosis is readily made on endoscopy. Both intramural rupture and intramural haematoma can be managed conservatively. Symptoms usually resolve in 7–14 days, and oral intake can be reinstituted as

soon as symptoms allow

Statement 4:  The condition presents with hematemesis. Usually, the bleeding is not severe, but endoscopic injection therapy may be required for the occasional, severe case. Surgery is rarely required.

 Reference : Bailey and Love 27th Edition Pg. 1075

choices.text: Sengstaken Blakemore Tube Inflation and observation in ICU

questions.text: A 46 year old alcoholic patient presented to the casualty with complaints of hematemesis. He had 3 similar episodes in the past and is a known case of chronic liver disease with esophageal varices. Based on his history, resuscitation was started in the casualty and the patient's blood labs were sent for. His Hb was 4.5g/dl. So Inj. Terlipressin was given. Emergency endoscopic treatment was done but it failed to control the bleed. What is the next best step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The emergency management of variceal haemorrhage has been revolutionised by the introduction of transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic stent shunts (TIPSS). Over a short period, this has become the main treatment of variceal

hemorrhage that has not responded to drug treatment and endoscopic therapy

 A satisfactory drop in portal venous pressure is usually associated with good control of the variceal hemorrhage. The main early complication of this technique is perforation of the liver capsule, which can be associated with fatal intraperitoneal hemorrhage. TIPSS occlusion may result in further

variceal haemorrhage and occurs more commonly in patients with well-compensated liver disease and good synthetic function

 The main contraindication to TIPSS is portal vein occlusion.

 The main long-term complication of TIPSS is stenosis of the shunt, which is common (approximately 50% at 1 year) and may present as further variceal hemorrhage.

Option B. The increasing availability of liver transplantation and TIPSS has greatly reduced the indications for surgical shunts. It is rarely considered for the acute management of variceal haemorrhage, as the morbidity and  mortality in these circumstances are high. The main current indication for a surgical shunt is a patient with CTP grade A cirrhosis, in whom the initial bleed has been controlled by sclerotherapy.

Option C. Esophageal transection with a stapling device is rapid and relatively simple, but rebleeding rates after this procedure are high. Moreover, there is little evidence that operative mortality rates are lower than after surgical portal decompression.

Option D. Controlled trials have demonstrated that balloon tamponade is as effective as pharmacotherapy and endoscopic therapy in controlling acute variceal bleeding. The major advantages of variceal tamponade using the Sengstaken-Blakemore tube are immediate cessation of bleeding in more than 85% of patients, as well as widespread availability of this device. However, there are also significant disadvantages of balloon tamponade, including frequent recurrent hemorrhage in up to 50% of patients after balloon deflation, considerable discomfort for the patient, and a high incidence of serious complications when used incorrectly by an inexperienced health care provider.

Hence, whenever available TIPS is usually the preferred management of Acute Refractory variceal Bleed.

Reference: Bailey and Love 27th Ediiton Pg. 1164 Sabiston 20th Edition Pg 1433

questions.text:
A 67 year old male patient was operated for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. In the post-operative period, the patient was not recovering well , had a pulse rate of 110/min, Blood Pressure of 104/62 mm Hg and a temperature of 102 F. He clinically had jaundice.
Following were the lab reports:
Hb - 10.5 , Wbc count- 22000, Platelet count - 2,50,000
S. Creat - 0.9, Total bilirubin - 2.5 mg/dl , direct bilirubin - 2.0 mg/dl
S. Sodium - 137 mEq/l and S. potassium- 3.0 mEq/l
Which of the Following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A and B. Patients who develop jaundice in the postoperative period require urgent investigation. This is especially true if the jaundice is associated with infection, a condition called cholangitis. The first step in management following resuscitation and administration of appropriate antibiotics is to undertake an urgent ultrasound scan. This will demonstrate whether there is intra- or extrahepatic ductal dilatation.

Option C and D.  The anatomy needs to be defined by either an ERCP or a MRCP. The former will also allow therapeutic manoeuvres such as removal of an obstructing stone or insertion of a stent across a biliary leak. If a fluid collection is present in the subhepatic space, drainage catheters may be required. These can be inserted under radiological control or, if this expertise is not available, at open operation. Small biliary leaks will usually resolve spontaneously, especially if there is no distal obstruction. Should the common bile duct be damaged, the patient should be referred to an appropriate expert for reconstruction of the duct.

Reference: Bailey and Love 27th Edition Pg No. – 1203

questions.text: A 10-year old boy presented with hydronephrosis on USG. The Best investigation to diagnose the Obstructive dilatation of collecting system is shown below: What is this investigation?
questions.solution:
• Isotope renography is the best test to confirm obstructive dilatation of the collecting system.
  • A substance (usually diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid (DTPA) or MAG-3) is injected intravenously.
  • The DTPA is labelled with technetium- 99m, a gamma-ray emitter, so that the passage of 99mTc-labelled DTPA through the kidneys can be tracked using a gamma camera.
  • 99mTc-DTPA is cleared from a normal kidney but stays in the renal pelvis on the obstructed side and is retained even if urine flow is increased by administering frusemide
  • Very occasionally, a Whitaker test is indicated. A percutaneous puncture of the kidney is made and fluid is infused at a constant rate with monitoring of intrapelvic pressure.
  • An abnormal rise in pressure confirms obstruction.

Ref. Bailey 27th Edition page 1412
